Name: NCA hydroxide production, for Li-ion battery | sodium sulfate, anhydrite | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: NCA hydroxide (NCA(OH)2) is produced by co-precipitation of nickel sulfate (NiSO4), manganese sulfate (MnSO4), and aluminium sulfate (Al2(SO4)3). The process begins with dissolving and mixing NiSO4, MnSO4 and Al2(SO4)3 in a tank reactor. Once the solution is completely dissolved and mixed, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) are added in the tank reactor, where nickel, manganese and aluminium co-precipitate in form of NCA(OH)2 (solid). Once precipitated, NCA(OH)2 is filtered out, washed, and dried to produce the NCA precursor. Sodium sulfate is produced as by-product. The conversion efficiency of the input materials in the reaction is 100%. The excess of ammonia is removed in an ammonia stripping tower, and recycled for subsequent precursor production. ;Reference:;Dai, Q., Kelly, J. C., Dunn, J., & Benavides, P. (2018a). Update of Bill-of-Materials and Cathode Materials Production for Lithium-Ion Batteries in the GREET Model. 2018. Argonne National Laboratory.
